description: Evidence-based Treatment Plan Generator Rules for MHT Assessment

absoluteContraindications.rationale: Active or recent breast cancer is an absolute contraindication to systemic HRT

absoluteContraindications.recommendation: Do not start systemic HRT - consider alternatives
absoluteContraindications.rationale: Active or recent VTE is an absolute contraindication to systemic HRT

absoluteContraindications.recommendation: Investigate unexplained bleeding before considering HRT
absoluteContraindications.rationale: Unexplained vaginal bleeding requires investigation before HRT initiation

absoluteContraindications.recommendation: Do not start HRT with active liver disease
absoluteContraindications.rationale: Active liver disease is a contraindication to HRT

relativeContraindications.recommendation: Consider alternatives to systemic HRT due to high cardiovascular risk
relativeContraindications.rationale: ASCVD risk >20% suggests increased cardiovascular risk with systemic HRT

relativeContraindications.recommendation: High VTE risk - avoid oral HRT, consider transdermal if appropriate
relativeContraindications.rationale: High Wells score indicates elevated VTE risk with oral HRT

relativeContraindications.recommendation: Smoking increases HRT risks - prioritize smoking cessation
relativeContraindications.rationale: Smoking combined with HRT increases cardiovascular and VTE risks

relativeContraindications.recommendation: Consider HRT benefits for bone protection in high fracture risk
relativeContraindications.rationale: High FRAX score may justify HRT for bone protection benefits

primaryRecommendations.recommendation: Consider systemic HRT - lowest effective dose, shortest duration

details.firstLine: Oral estradiol with progestogen (if uterus present) OR transdermal estradiol
details.dosing: Start with lowest effective dose - estradiol 1mg daily or 25-50mcg patch
details.duration: Review annually, consider duration vs benefits
details.route: Oral or transdermal - patient preference and risk factors

primaryRecommendations.rationale: Low risk profile with significant symptoms supports HRT as first-line therapy
primaryRecommendations.monitoring: Baseline: BP, BMI, breast exam. Follow-up: 3 months, then annually

primaryRecommendations.recommendation: HRT may be considered with enhanced monitoring

details.firstLine: Transdermal estradiol preferred to minimize VTE risk
details.dosing: Conservative dosing - estradiol 25mcg patch twice weekly

primaryRecommendations.rationale: Moderate risk requires careful risk-benefit assessment

primaryRecommendations.recommendation: Consider non-hormonal options first for mild symptoms

details.approach: Step-wise approach starting with lowest-risk options

primaryRecommendations.rationale: Mild symptoms may respond to lower-risk interventions
primaryRecommendations.monitoring: Symptom assessment at 6-8 weeks, consider HRT if inadequate response

vaginal_estrogen.name: Vaginal Estrogen
vaginal_estrogen.dosing: Estradiol vaginal tablets 10mcg daily for 2 weeks, then twice weekly
vaginal_estrogen.benefits: Minimal systemic absorption, effective for urogenital symptoms
vaginal_estrogen.risks: Minimal systemic effects, local irritation possible
vaginal_estrogen.monitoring: Annual review, no routine endometrial monitoring needed

ssri_snri.name: SSRIs/SNRIs
ssri_snri.benefits: No cancer or VTE risk, may help mood symptoms
ssri_snri.risks: Sexual dysfunction, GI effects, drug interactions

clonidine.name: Clonidine
clonidine.indication: Vasomotor symptoms, particularly when HRT contraindicated
clonidine.benefits: No hormonal effects, may help sleep
clonidine.risks: Hypotension, dry mouth, sedation, rebound hypertension
clonidine.monitoring: BP monitoring essential, gradual withdrawal required

lifestyle.name: Lifestyle Modifications
lifestyle.interventions: Weight management, regular exercise, smoking cessation, stress reduction
lifestyle.benefits: Overall health benefits, no medication risks

cbt.name: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy
cbt.approach: Structured CBT program for menopause symptoms
cbt.benefits: Addresses psychological aspects, no medication risks
cbt.evidence: Good evidence for hot flash reduction and mood improvement

bisphosphonates.name: Bisphosphonates
bisphosphonates.benefits: Proven fracture reduction, no cancer risk
bisphosphonates.risks: GI intolerance, osteonecrosis of jaw (rare), atypical fractures

baseline_hrt.name: Baseline Assessment for HRT
optional: Lipid profile if cardiovascular risk factors

hrt_benefits: Effective relief of vasomotor symptoms (hot flashes, night sweats)
Improvement in sleep quality and mood
Prevention of bone loss and fracture risk reduction
Potential cardiovascular benefits if started early
hrt_risks: Small increased risk of breast cancer with long-term use
Increased risk of VTE, particularly with oral preparations
Possible increased stroke risk in older women
Return of menstrual bleeding with some regimens
Breast tenderness and mood changes possible
shared_decision_points: Lowest effective dose for shortest duration principle
Alternative treatments available if HRT unsuitable
Patient preferences and values crucial in decision-making
